results.title: Back to the past: Westbourne Grammar School
results.brief_description:
Back to the Past or “Screening Melbourne” is designed to encourage students to develop an appreciation for the art and the craft behind moving image in its many forms by developing their ability to think beyond the screen. In the program Students become actors in a sci-fi time travel film story during a blue-screen workshop that allows them to place themselves in a historical Melbourne setting, engage with a screening program featuring historical Melbourne footage and participate in a related discussion
learn some simple editing skills while they create a digital ‘Melbourne travelogue’
Back to the Past aims to develop students’ understanding of ways in which film-makers create screen texts to target particular audiences. Students in Years 3-4 learn about concepts related to camera use such as framing, shot types, and angles as well as some of the features of documentary and blue-screen technology.
Features Charles “Bud” Tingwell

results.title: Fairytales and Fantasy Workshops: Carlton North Primary 18 July 2005: Groups A and B
results.brief_description:
Fairy Tales and Fantasy is an ACMI screen education program designed to encourage students to begin to develop an appreciation for the art and the craft behind moving image in its many forms, by developing their ability to think beyond the screen. Fairy Tales and Fantasy aims to develop students’ understanding of ways in which film-makers create screen texts. Students in Years 1-2 learn about:
- three key stages of plot development
- main elements of the fairy tale genre
- simple concepts related to camera use such as framing, shot types, angles
- the magic of blue-screen technology
- become actors in a short film during a blue-screen workshop that allows them to place themselves in a magical, fairy tale setting
- engage with a film program featuring traditional and non-traditional fairy tales, and participate in a related discussion
- learn some simple editing skills while they create a fairy tale story
- view their ACMI creations.
Fairy Tales and Fantasy and activities provided in the accompanying Teacher Kit are designed to assist students to develop a range of Screen Literacy outcomes. The program is also designed to assist students to develop understandings about the ways in which stories help us to make sense of the world and our place in that world. People all over the world tell stories in many different ways using oral, written and visual texts. This program and related activities enables students to share their experiences of story and to extend and refine their understandings by comparing a range of fairy tale and fantasy texts, analysing narrative structure and exploring animation and film adaptations of fairy tales.

results.title: [The Flying potato]
results.creator_credit: Tarnagulla and Marong Primary Schools and Paul Fletcher
results.brief_description: Work created by students from Tarnagulla and Marong primary schools with animator Paul Fletcher as part of the artists in schools program sponsored by the Department of Education and Arts Victoria. Contains original artwork by the students (from lower primary levels) that has been animated by the artist, footage of the students and animations created by the older students. Storyline is minimal but includes a flying potato adventure, a monster circus and experimental animation.

results.title: Victoria's favourite things
results.brief_description:
Check out what people brought to ACMI for July’s Open House weekend program
‘Victoria’s Favourite Things’. Recorded live in ACMI’s Screen Pit, the event was modelled on a 1960’s variety show and includes songs, stories, bad jokes and some really interesting stuff.

results.title: Victoria's Favourite Things. Segment 11
results.brief_description: The results of July 2004’s Open House weekend program ‘Victoria’s Favourite Things’. This segment features Kenton from Nundawading who just loves life and the state of Victoria; a woman who has four deeply meaningful Rings; Nairee and Michelle from Traralgon tell us about ‘my dog Oscar’; and Adrian from Brunswick has a passion for Melbourne’s live music scene.

results.title: Victoria's Favourite Things. Segment 10
results.brief_description: The results of July 2004’s Open House weekend program ‘Victoria’s Favourite Things’. This segment features Michael who shares his love of imagination; Ivan and Luke really like Dinosaurs; Madelaine from Clayton is a BIG fan of Horses; and Michelle from Frankston’s favourite thing is absolutely the beach.

results.title: Victoria's Favourite Things. Segment 9
results.brief_description: The results of July 2004’s Open House weekend program ‘Victoria’s Favourite Things’. This segment features Maya and her fairy costume; Jennifer from Regent talks about Bernadette and Lucinda; Kieran from St Kilda loves football; Kay has a favourite hat and scarf; and Monica from Avondale Heights talks about Meditation.

results.title: Victoria's Favourite Things. Segment 8
results.brief_description: The results of July 2004’s Open House weekend program ‘Victoria’s Favourite Things’. This segment features Madelaine talking about her love of clothes; Emma from Fitzroy’s favourite thing is sleeping; Sarah, Melanie and Hayley from Cranbourne really dig Lord Of The Rings (and friendship); and Jack from Surrey Hills talks about his Yu Gi Oh Model Kit.

results.title: Victoria's Favourite Things. Segment 7
results.brief_description: The results of July 2004’s Open House weekend program ‘Victoria’s Favourite Things’. This segment features Jenny from Tasmania talking about her favourite place - Melbourne - and the warm coat she wears when she visits; Ripponlea cherishes her memories; Casey from Hastings just loves hockey; Lucy and Chloe are favourite friends; and Clemet talks about Victoria and Melbourne City.

results.title: Victoria's Favourite Things. Segment 6
results.brief_description: The results of July 2004’s Open House weekend program ‘Victoria’s Favourite Things’. This segment features Alan from Balwyn North talking about the Collingwood footy team; John from Port Melbourne chats about his cherished remote control; Susy of Beaumaris and Victoria from Elwood both have a passion for writing; Camile of Warburton just loves going to the beach; Jack loves the outdoors, skiing and building snowmen; Fiona from St Kilda has a favourite hat; Matthew and Michael favour trains and soccer; and Rosemary’s favourite things are her five children.
